nexttext:
where $\mu \in (0,1)$ is the mass ratio of the two primaries. We call the origin ${(0,0)}$ the Earth and the point $(1,0)$ the Moon. The massless body will be referred to as the satellite.  In what follows, we  consider  only negative energies. Notice that for a negative energy, the motion of the satellite is bounded. We further assume that ${ \mu \leq 1/2}$. In other words, the Earth is stronger.  The unique critical point of the Hamiltonian is a point $\mathcal{L}=(l,0,0,0)$, where $ 0<l<1$, 
namely the critical point lies between the Earth and the Moon.  It is easy to see that the critical point $\mathcal{L}$ has Morse index 1. 

 \;\;

 As ${ \mu \rightarrow 0}$, the Euler problem degenerates to the Kepler problem.   As mentioned in the introduction, the Euler problem has no rotational symmetry, i.e., $L$ is not an integral of this problem. However, it is still a completely integrable system. The integral is given by

\times{\mathbb{R}}^{2}\rightarrow{\mathbb{R}},\;\;\;(q,p)\mapsto\frac{1}{2}|p|%
^{2}-\frac{1-\mu}{|q|}-\frac{\mu}{|q-1|}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>H</mi><mi>μ</mi></msub><mo>:</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo maxsize="120%" minsize="120%">(</mo><mrow><msup><mi>ℝ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>∖</mo><mrow><mo>{</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>}</mo></mrow></mrow><mo maxsize="120%" minsize="120%">)</mo></mrow><mo>×</mo><msup><mi>ℝ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo>→</mo><mi>ℝ</mi></mrow><mo rspace="10.9pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>q</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>p</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>↦</mo><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>p</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mi>μ</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><mi>q</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
where $\mu \in (0,1)$ is the mass ratio of the two primaries. We call the origin ${(0,0)}$ the Earth and the point $(1,0)$ the Moon. The massless body will be referred to as the satellite.  In what follows, we  consider  only negative energies. Notice that for a negative energy, the motion of the satellite is bounded. We further assume that ${ \mu \leq 1/2}$. In other words, the Earth is stronger.  The unique critical point of the Hamiltonian is a point $\mathcal{L}=(l,0,0,0)$, where $ 0<l<1$, 
namely the critical point lies between the Earth and the Moon.  It is easy to see that the critical point $\mathcal{L}$ has Morse index 1. 

 \;\;

 As ${ \mu \rightarrow 0}$, the Euler problem degenerates to the Kepler problem.   As mentioned in the introduction, the Euler problem has no rotational symmetry, i.e., $L$ is not an integral of this problem. However, it is still a completely integrable system. The integral is given by

nexttext:
As (i), we compute that
\begin{eqnarray*}
 \frac{ \partial k_1^2}{\partial c} &=& \frac{ 2 \mu(1-\mu)}{ \big( c^2 - 2(1-2\mu)c+1\big)^{3/2}} >0 \\
\frac{\partial R_{\text{ext}}^E}{\partial c} &=& \frac{\pi}{2 (1-2k_1^2)^{3/2} K(k_1)^2 } \frac{\partial k_1^2}{\partial c} \bigg( K(k_1) - (1-2k_1^2) \frac{\partial K}{\partial k_1^2} \bigg) \\
&=& \frac{\pi^2}{4 (1-2k_1^2)^{3/2} K(k_1)^2 } \frac{\partial k_1^2}{\partial c}  \bigg( \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}  \frac{ (2n-1)!! (2n+1)!!}{(2n)!!(2n+2)!!} \frac{ 2n+3}{2} k_1^{2n}\bigg) > 0.
\end{eqnarray*}
Moreover,

\begin{eqnarray*}
 \frac{ \partial k_1^2}{\partial c} &=& \frac{ 2 \mu(1-\mu)}{ \big( c^2 - 2(1-2\mu)c+1\big)^{3/2}} >0 \\
\frac{\partial R_{\text{ext}}^E}{\partial c} &=& \frac{\pi}{2 (1-2k_1^2)^{3/2} K(k_1)^2 } \frac{\partial k_1^2}{\partial c} \bigg( K(k_1) - (1-2k_1^2) \frac{\partial K}{\partial k_1^2} \bigg) \\
&=& \frac{\pi^2}{4 (1-2k_1^2)^{3/2} K(k_1)^2 } \frac{\partial k_1^2}{\partial c}  \bigg( \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}  \frac{ (2n-1)!! (2n+1)!!}{(2n)!!(2n+2)!!} \frac{ 2n+3}{2} k_1^{2n}\bigg) > 0.
\end{eqnarray*}
